content: The National Advisory Commission on Tax Reform and Simplification Act of 2000 establishes a commission to study and provide recommendations to Congress on simplifying, reforming, or replacing the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The Congress acknowledges that the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is overly complex, burdensome, and difficult to administer, leading to taxpayer difficulties and calls for simplification. The current tax code is overly complex, leading to burdens for individual filers and the need to turn to tax professionals for help. Congress's continual modifications add to the confusion, but the government's budget surplus provides an opportunity for reform and simplification of the tax laws. Recent efforts to simplify or reform the tax laws have faced challenges in gaining broad-based, nonpartisan support for proposed changes. Establishment of a National Commission on Tax Reform and Simplification. The National Advisory Commission on Tax Reform and Simplification, established within the legislative branch, consists of 15 members appointed by various leaders from the executive and legislative branches, as well as private individuals. The National Advisory Commission on Tax Reform and Simplification, established within the legislative branch, consists of 15 members appointed by various leaders from the executive and legislative branches, as well as private individuals. 2 members appointed by the minority leader of the House of Representatives, 1 from Members of the House of Representatives and 1 from private life. The President and congressional leadership should draw from a number of important areas of expertise in composing the Commission, including tax experts familiar with corporate tax issues, international tax issues, small business tax issues, and family and individual tax issues. Appointments to the Commission shall be made not later than 45 days after the date of the enactment of this Act. SEC. 5. RULES OF THE COMMISSION. The Commission shall consist of nine members for quorum. After 60 days of enactment, if 5 or more members are appointed, they can select a Chair to start operations, including staff hiring. The Commission may establish additional rules and fill vacancies in the same manner as initial appointments. Meetings can be held in executive session if deemed appropriate by the Chair or majority of members. Any individual appointed to the Commission can continue as a member for up to 30 days after ceasing the position that led to their appointment. SEC. 6. DUTIES OF THE COMMISSION. The Commission's duties include conducting a review of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 for up to 18 months and submitting a report to Congress with recommendations for reform and simplification. The review will focus on the code's impact on the economy, families, and the workforce. The Commission will review the tax code's impact on the economy, families, and the workforce, including tax burden distribution, predictability, compliance costs, and IRS administration. They will also consider if other countries' tax systems could be more efficient, if income tax should be replaced, and if the tax code can be simplified without major restructuring. The Commission, subcommittees, or members can hold hearings, take testimony, and administer oaths to carry out the Act. The Commission can enter contracts to fulfill its duties, and can obtain information from federal agencies and offices. The Commission can obtain information, suggestions, estimates, and statistics from government departments and agencies for its review and report. The Secretary of the Treasury can provide administrative support to the Commission. The Administrator of the General Services Administration can also assist the Commission. The Commission on Taxation can receive administrative support services from the General Services Administration and legal, economic, or policy analysis from the Joint Committee on Taxation. Additionally, other departments and agencies of the United States can provide various support services to the Commission as needed. The Commission on Taxation can receive support services from various departments and agencies of the United States. The Commission is authorized to use the United States mails and accept gifts or donations in carrying out its duties under this Act. The Commission on Taxation is authorized to receive support services from different US departments and agencies, use the US mails, and accept gifts or donations. The Commission on Taxation can appoint a staff director and other necessary personnel without following standard government hiring procedures. The staff director's pay cannot exceed that of a level V Executive Schedule position. Federal employees can be detailed to the Commission without reimbursement, retaining their regular rights and privileges. The Commission can procure consultant services at rates not exceeding level IV of the Executive Schedule. SEC. 9. COMPENSATION AND TRAVEL EXPENSES. Members of the Commission may be compensated at a daily rate not exceeding the annual rate of basic pay for level IV positions. Exceptions apply for government officials and Members of Congress who serve on the Commission. Travel expenses, including per diem, are allowed for Commission members when away from their homes or regular places of business. Members of the Commission are allowed travel expenses, including per diem, in the same manner as intermittent government employees under section 5703(b) of title 5, United States Code. The Commission members are entitled to travel expenses, including per diem, as intermittent government employees under section 5703(b) of title 5, United States Code. Additionally, the Commission is required to submit a report and terminate its activities. The Commission must submit a report to the House Ways and Means Committee and Senate Finance Committee within 18 months of its first meeting. The report should include recommendations for simplifying the tax code and describe the expected impact on the economy. The Commission will terminate 90 days after submitting the report. The Commission may use the 90-day period for concluding activities, including testifying to Congress and disseminating the report. Authorization of appropriations is available for Commission activities, with $2,000,000 from fiscal year 2001 funds until specific appropriations are made.
